A wealthy businessman who lived a life of luxury paid just £35.20 income tax, a BBC investigation has discovered.

Frank Timis rented a £14,000-a-month penthouse and spent thousands dining in London's finest restaurants.

But his personal tax return for 2017 shows he paid just £35.20 in tax, after claiming that he had hardly any income from his worldwide business empire.

Mr Timis's lawyers say he has fully complied with all of his tax obligations.

Stifel with the summary:

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Trading under pressure. Due to volume pressures in the group's Highways, Utilities
and Housing Maintenance businesses, and lower-than-anticipated revenue in Buildings,
sales in FY19E are now expected to be in line with FY18A (we previously forecast 5.1%
sales growth including JVs). This is equivalent to a c.£250m cut in sales guidance. As a
result of these trading pressures, operating profit is set to be c.£25m lower than previous
expectations.
Update on Future Proofing Kier (FPK). The net costs associated with the FPK
programme for FY19E are now expected to be c.£15m higher than previously forecast
(prior guidance break-even), in part due to an acceleration of the programme following
the appointment of Andrew Davies as CEO. Kier will provide a further update on FPK
when it announces the conclusions to its strategic review.
Due to the above £25m lower profit from trading and £15m increased cost from FPK,
updated guidance is for FY19E operating profit to be £40m lower than prior expectations
(Stifel prior forecast £168.8m), a 24% cut. The group will provide updated guidance for
FY20 and its FY19 prelims on 19 September 2019.
Net debt worse than expected. The group is likely to report a net position as at 30 June
2019 (previous guidance year-end net cash), impacted by lower profitability and sales
growth (impacting working capital). This adversely impacts the average month-end net
debt position (prior FY19 forecast: £320m).
Strategic review. The group is undertaking a strategic review focused on simplification,
the allocation of capital resources and steps to improve cash generation and improve
leverage. The results of the strategic review are due to be announced on 30 July.
Target price methodology/risks
Our target price of 430p is based on a sum-of-the-parts valuation that applies appropriate
EV/EBITA multiples to the contracting divisions and cost value for the asset-intensive
businesses. Shareholder obligations are then deducted. We then take a 30% discount
given our concerns on working capital, political risk and earnings quality.
The main risks to the upside include an uplift in underlying cash conversion, supported
by FPK, driving a material improvement in investor sentiment.
The key risks to the downside include a slowdown in UK construction, infrastructure and
residential markets, contract execution issues and a change in government policy on
outsourcing and infrastructure investment.

We expect a c. £250m reduction in total revenues. Assuming c. 10% gross margin we reduce gross
profit by £25m. There will also be a further £15m of restructuring costs which may or may not be
treated above the line. We assume they are. We assume £3m of additional interest in FY 2019. We
expect an update on the FPK program in July and more detailed guidance for 2020 at the Prelims.
Whilst the cost savings should fully benefit 2020 we expect that Andrew Davies will take a cautious
approach to guidance.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

He's shop broker, so don't take the "buy" rating too serious.

BE11:24am

Management has previously guided to spot net cash at the FY. We assume a c. £70m adverse swing
from net cash of £38m to net debt of £36m. This comprises a £40m reduction in profits and a c.£30m
additional working capital outflow. Crudely, there is 15% negative working capital absorption on the
£250m sales reduction, which could result in a £38m impact.

Last week we reduced our TP from £6.00 to £4.00 as further downgrades were anticipated. Today we
reduce the TP from £4.00 to £3.20, less than the downgrade. The revised CY19 EV/EBIT of 4.5x is a
little below the sector average of 5.4x. Risks also look discounted on a P/E of 4.5x, versus the sector
average of 7.4x.

11:24 am
JP11:24am

Kier has announced that the Highways, Utilities and Housing Maintenance volume headwinds (flagged in March) have persisted into H2. Also, whilst Buildings remains strong, volumes will be lower than expected (due in part to macro-related delays). In response, Kier is accelerating its FPK efficiency programme (£15m above-the-line impact). Consequently we reduce our FY19 PBT from £150m to £110m to give EPS of 67.5p (from 92.1p). We expect FY19 net debt of £60m (vs cash of £15m). Although the shares are likely to be under pressure, this may herald a turning point for Kier. A new management team is taking shape and the strategic review (30 July) should provide a roadmap to recovery. Despite the earnings uncertainty, there is asset support (Price/Book 0.7x) and market-leading positions. We see value, but await further insight before being able to conclude a target price.

JP11:25am

Trading details in Infrastructure (37% EBITA): the volume pressures referenced at the H1 stage in Highways and Utilities have persisted. As well as the revenue impact (PHe £120m), the largely fixed overhead results in a £13m reduction in our divisional EBITA assumption. In Buildings (35% EBITA) the market backdrop remains good, but we have reduced our revenue assumption by £100m to reflect some macro-related project delays (a £10m EBITA impact). In Property and Development we make a small revision in relation to Housing Management given the previously-flagged volume pressure. However, progress elsewhere is in line. In aggregate, the trading-related EBITA reduction is £25m. In response management is accelerating the FPK programme and central costs will now be £15m higher than previously assumed (benefits to accrue in FY20).

JP11:25am

Estimates – We reduce our Jun’19 PBT from £150m to £110m to give EPS of 67.5p from 92.1p. We now assume closing net debt of £60m (vs cash £15m) given the profit and working capital impact (£40m), with average net debt of £360m (vs prior guidance of £320m). Management will formally update FY20 guidance in September, but given the lower earnings base and likely FPK net charges (taken above-the-line), we now assume PBT of £145m from £186m to give EPS of 71p (from 91.0p). We assume average net debt of £280m. Our dividend reductions reflect the lower earnings base. Facilities of £985m span to 2024 (RCF to 2022).

11:25 am
JP11:25am

Strategic review – Andrew Davies (CEO) will deliver his strategic review on 30 July. The focus is on simplifying the group, the allocation of capital and additional steps to improve cash generation and reduce leverage. The shares have been under pressure and would appear to have been discounting a cautious year-end trading update ahead of the strategic review. Whilst disappointing, we note that the asset support, market-leading positions across a number of key markets and forthcoming strategic review should provide some support today.

JP11:45am

Well, Charles Hall at Peel Hunt has the details:

11:45 am
JP11:45am

FCA to regulate funeral plans HMT’s investigation into the funeral plan sector has concluded that it should be under the remit of the FCA. This is in line with our expectations and is a sensible move given the risk of mis-selling and protection of customer assets. In particular, it should limit the hard-sell techniques of some companies. Dignity has been clear in calling for regulation, which should reduce competition in the sector, albeit that it is likely to reduce the overall sales given less promotional activity and as funeral prices are unlikely to increase. The investigation into funeral plans will continue as the CMA recently widened the scope of its investigation to include them at point of redemption.

JP11:45am

Importance for Dignity Dignity sold 58,000 plans (with its affiliates) out of the total market of 177,000 last year, giving it a share of 33%, which compares to the company’s 12% share of the overall funeral market. The company performed 19,400 funerals last year funded by funeral plans, equating to 27% of its total funerals undertaken. The overall number of plans outstanding was 486,000, which equates to over six years of its annual funeral volumes.

JP11:46am

Implications of FCA oversight HMT has set out the costs of bringing funerals under FCA oversight. The total transition is expected to take two years and cost £5.4m with an annual cost of £0.3m. HMT estimates that the cost for funeral plan providers will be broadly neutral as the levy for the FCA will be offset by the removal of fees currently paid to the Funeral Planning Authority. Nonetheless, there will inevitably be increased costs to the industry from having to address the additional supervision from the FCA. There are also likely to be material restrictions on the ability to promote products. The Co-op and Dignity are clearly at the right end of the spectrum of providers when it comes to marketing. However, they will also have to change practices in order to avoid any semblance of mis-selling as well as the persistence of follow-up activity. The FCA oversight will also include the administration of plan owners’ money after they have purchased a plan, handling of claims and payment of plan contracts.

11:45 am
JP11:46am

Long-term impact Initially we see little change for Dignity; however, the risk is that oversight by the FCA will be considerably more onerous and the number of plans sold will reduce given that companies will no longer be able to highlight rising prices of funerals in their marketing material nor chase people after initial inquiries.

JP11:46am

Price target of 600p, so around 15 per cent downside from here.

BE11:47am

Cool, that summarises that.

That's Infineon, as in .... The main argument seems to be on price.

BE11:51am

Here's UBS with the balanced view.

Soundbuy @Forester - more DIY than DTY..............
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Infineon has this morning announced its intention to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY) for €9.0bn enterprise value, paying $23.85 per share. This is a c50% premium to the undisturbed price CY was trading on last week. It values CY on 19.5x P/E and 16.7x EV/EBITDA (IBES consensus, pre synergies) '20E compared to Infineon currently trading on 15x/7x respectively. Infineon says it will pay for CY shares in cash financed in the short-term by a bridging loan and then will issue shares to cover c30% of the acquisition in due course. Infineon targets €180m of cost synergies (something on which we believe it executed well on post the IRF acquisition) and potential to generate €1.5bn of sales synergies long-term. We are working on a full merger model but we would estimate potential EPS accretion of 20-30% to FY21 (based on IBES consensus and assuming €120m cost synergy and €400m sales) and rising beyond. At first glance, we think the proposed deal appears expensive on an EV multiple basis, and we think its success will likely depend on the ability to extract sales synergies to generate a strong return on capital. The deal is subject to a number of regulatory approvals.

BE11:52am

We see a number of positives of the deal: 1) CY is focused on autos (37% of sales) and IoT (38% of sales) which suggests good end market synergy. 2) Despite the end market overlap between IFX/CY, we believe there is limited actual product overlap limited dissynergy risk (often the key challenge in acquisition in this space). We believe the combination could help IFX to provide broader solutions to customers. IFX believes it can achieve €1.5bn sales synergies long-term and 9%+ combined growth. 3) Given CY's greater use of outsourcing (63% foundry) it should lower the capital intensity for the same growth opportunity and segment margin is targeted at 19% (was 17%+).

BE11:52am

We would see the following negatives: 1) Within CY's own definition of its business, 25% of sales are 'Legacy' and likely to decline going forward. 2) The acquisition will dilute the exposure IFX has to both power and the EV story. 3) The price paid appears expensive and the deal will depend particularly on sales synergies to deliver real value.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

And Citi ....

Blank canvas Thanks for everything today.
BE11:53am

Our initial view is that the overall risk-reward profile of the deal is unfavorable, as scale & diversification benefits are more than offset by diminished positioning appeal, hard-to-substantiate revenue synergies and execution / regulatory risks. As such the deal requires investors to take a longer-term leap of faith, which we believe will prove hard amidst an uncertain near-term demand backdrop. Our thesis is under review.

BE11:53am

We believe one of the key investment appeals
of Infineon has been its automotive & industrial exposure, and within automotive, particularly its exposure to higher-growth safety and powertrain applications. In our view, the combined entity would boast of increased exposure to body & infotainment application in automotive, consumer in terms of overall end-markets and digital in terms of product portfolio. This diminishes the overall positioning appeal in our view.

11:53 am
JP11:54am

To your point on a recent lack of consolidation in the sector BE, here's a nice chart from Neil Campling of Mirabaud..

JP11:54am

JP11:54am

And a few of his thoughts on the deal:

11:54 am
JP11:54am

We can see the Industrial logic of a deal for Infineon to acquire Cypress but there are bigger issues at play which could kybosh the deal. Don’t forget that the last time Infineon attempted to acquire US assets, the Wolfspeed division of Cree, the deal was terminated citing security concerns raised by the U.S. government back in 2017. We wonder if Infineon is placing a strategic ‘bet’ here that the trade issues between the U.S. and China will be resolved by the time the deal reaches the relevant approval authorities? CFIUS will obviously review the deal involving a US entity and China will review the deal because the merger-filing thresholds in China are low. All deals in which each participant has a turnover of at least RMB 2B or a total turnover of least RMB 10B. Infineon posted €1.9 China revenues (RMB 14.7B) in FY18 so easily topping the RMB10B total revenue consideration - so MOFCOM would review.

BE11:54am

Yeah, it's the usual story of consolidation happening at the peaks rather than the troughs.

JP11:54am

The industrial logic of the deal with complimentary overlap and a general longer term trend of Moore’s law based consolidation. Yet the value of deals in the industry has shrunk considerably since the record days of 2015 when $107B of semiconductor deals were completed. The two largest deals that were completed in 2018 were in the exact same space that Cypress and Infineon compete in (perhaps given confidence to go for this deal?); fabless mixed-signal IC and power discrete semiconductor supplier Microsemi agreed to be acquired by Microchip Technology for $8.35 billion in cash. Microchip said the purchase of Microsemi would boost its position in computing, communications, and wireless systems applications. The transaction was completed in May 2018. Fabless mixed-signal IC supplier Integrated Device Technology (IDT) agreed in September 2018 to be purchased by Renesas Electronics for $6.7 billion in cash. Renesas targeted the deal to strengthen its position in automotive ICs for advanced driver-assistance systems and autonomous vehicles. The IDT purchase was completed in April 2019.

11:54 am
JP11:55am

By end-market Cypress has 37% revenue exposure to autos and 28% to IoT (with 35% legacy) and by segment 58% of sales for MCU and connectivity (with 48% memory). 85% of R&D has been focused on auto and IoT, so it is pretty clear in which technologies Cypress has been focused. In autos the company is #1 in; auto USB-C, auto NOR (flash storage 68% market share), auto touch MCUs (46% share), auto cluster MCUs and in Wi-Fi/Bluetooth auto combo chips. Competitors include Microchip, NXP, Renesas and Micron. The competitors are notable as they’re all at the forefront of major consolidation, through acquisitions, in the semiconductor market over the last few years. Microchip acquired Microsemi, NXP acquired Marvell’s wireless connectivity business unit, Renesas acquired Integrated Device Technology and Micron acquired Intel’s stake in IM Flash.

In the focus 32-Bit MCU market Cypress is #7 by revenues, Infineon #4 with, which together would be battling for #2 position with NXP (Renesas #1 and STMicro currently #3).

JP11:55am

Cypress, under the Cypress 3.0 strategy, has gone through the heavy lifting already in restructuring the company. A go-to-market strategy has doubled down on connect and compute, streamlined portfolio to focus on differentiated products, restructured NOR to auto and high-density, divested Fab and improved utilization.

Just last week, at an investor conference, Cypress CEO thought that the industry wasn’t “done with consolidation” and how talk “has never stopped, although the public announcements have kind of slowed down” because where there were “a lot of companies in play, deals didn't close”. Over all China exposure for Cypress stands at about 40% of business: but then this is split about 50/50 with regards to half of it coming back to the U.S. and other part of the world, and about half of it is indigenous. The actual direct china auto business is very small with Cypress only entering the market just over two years ago. This acquisition represents about 2.6x TV/Revenue (slightly above comp median deals of 2.43x) and 39.4x TV/EBIT (way above 18.5x comp median) although the range of deal comps vary considerably. Other expensive deals include Microchip’s deal for Microsemi which was completed at 5.3x TV/Revenue and 36x TV/EBIT (and before Microchip realized Microsemi had been ‘stuffing the channel’) and Renesas’s 7.45x TV/Revenue and 49x TV/EBIT paid to IDTI.

On the call: revenue synergies will be very low in 2021 because of the one year design in cycle time. 19% segment margin target is a through cycle target but not until 2022 after the full integration of the deal.

So, in summary, a deal that while it makes sense on a technology basis it is one which faces significant questions over regulatory overhang, a cycle peak price at a time cycle is at trough and visibility is low and deal synergies in this space aren’t as easy as the appear on paper.

11:58 am
JP11:58am

Denial and complacency a feature of some 2019 company outlooks: The time to buy chemical shares is normally after a series of setbacks and share price corrections, or ahead of a likely period of upward estimate revisions. Neither are likely for now, with forecasts finely balanced with little material upside - and plenty of scope for reductions and cuts as key end markets remain cautious and nervous of increasing order patterns. The mistake that some management teams may be making is optimistically following customer protestations that things will be better in the second half. Why?

JP11:58am

Investors should try to look beyond a sluggish 2019: With forecasts under threat from more subdued demand as always it is only fair to identify the companies to buy when the time is right. We adjust forecasts overleaf following Q1 results, and reiterate Buys on Arkema due to its low valuation, and Lanxess due to its continued focus of restructuring from a low base. We also have a Buy rating on BASF - which has issued several profit warnings or ad hoc announcements over the last year - but this is focused on a possible capital return once Oil & Gas is floated in 2020, and investor hopes for portfolio realignment, rather than short-term trading.

JP11:58am

Fashionable to focus on EVs & high performance plastics - but hiccups here: Umicore surprised the market with a profit warning based partly on the Chinese subsidy reduction for EVs, along with other negatives such as higher cobalt prices. The net result is that in total this delays capacity expansion by 12-18 months. Victrex, too, has seen forecasts cut due to weaker demand in its range of polymers with the move to plastic from metals discounted by the increased range of competition as many companies are specialising in "high performance" plastics.

Our forecasts at constant FX assume 5% EBIT growth in Solutions (better than FY19), flat profits in Sweeteners (ditto), low £50m's EBIT in Sucralose (in line with directional guidance) and £10m commodities (below average & implied guidance but well above trough) This yields 50.8p EPS at actual fx/48.8p constant, the former relative to a 53p consensus and the latter reflecting a 6% y-o-y decline.

Peer-relative valuation looking decidedly stretched. At 720p, Tate is off its highs and Mexico is in the price, at least directionally. But the PER premium to close peer Ingredion (INGR) is a heady 30%, with Tate having outperformed INGR in $ by 65% since the US presidential election. Our 620p PT reflects a fair PER of 11.7x, still a 10% premium to INGR

From Berenberg:

BE12:06pm

Summary: Scapa has announced that ConvaTec Inc, one of the company’s largest customers,
served notice on Friday 31 May that it intends to remove its master supply agreement (MSA).
Notification was received after market close and was accompanied by an “action for
declaratory judgement”, which has been filed with the federal court in New Jersey. Scapa
states that this contract termination is “material”, although no guidance on profit numbers
has been given. The company has given guidance of a $30m revenue loss only. Management
has indicated a further update will follow in due course.
● At this stage we have limited details on the grounds for Convatec’s decision and whether it
can in fact terminate the contract given there is still three years remaining on the supply
agreement. Scapa says that it “does not accept that Convatec has any grounds” to purse the
termination. From our understanding a declaratory judgement does not typically implicate
damages, but simply provides legal certainty on the dispute at hand. However, Scapa has
indicated it will defend its right under the MSA and pursue all rights and remedies.
● In recent weeks Scapa released FY 2019 results showing strong progress, particularly in
growing its latest healthcare supply agreement with Systagenix. Unfortunately, this was
clouded by the resignation of CEO Heejae Chae, who had been instrumental in the
company’s success over the past decade, particularly in building the company’s healthcare
business. Today’s update is of course a setback. At this stage, however, we await more details
on any financial implications and legal certainty before making changes to numbers.
● Assuming the issue remains contained to the Convatec contract, we believe this would be a
loss of revenue in the region of c$30m. Assuming typical gross margins, we believe this
contract loss could see earnings downgrades c20% on an adjusted basis. However, this is
subject to error and we expect more financial guidance from the company in the coming
days and weeks.
